data.title: drums ‚Äì Kevin Trent Boswell
data.meta_description: Posts about drums written by Kevin Trent Boswell
data.text:
Late last year, I moved to Portland, Oregon. It‚Äôs a wonderfully weird place. The locals actually say, ‚ÄúKeep Portland weird.‚Äù There‚Äôs a large mural of that saying, somewhere in the city. Everything about this place is quirky, eccentric, and hence, I should fit in here, just fine.

I also started a new job. I‚Äôm working in the mental health field. No, I‚Äôm not a doctor, therapist, and definitely not a psychiatrist. I just work for a company that trains us to assist people who have one or more mental health diagnoses, addiction problems, or who have lived on the streets, but are now in reliable housing, provided by the state. It‚Äôs a good gig. I get paid well, to help the people who really need help the most.

On Friday night, it started snowing, the temperatures were bottoming out as low as 18¬∞F. That‚Äôs well below freezing, and it doesn‚Äôt even account for the windchill factor.

The other, less positive side of Portland, is that the homelessness crisis here is really bad. It‚Äôs almost impossible to go anywhere without seeing at least one car, RV, tent, or lean-to type shelter that someone is using to live in.

I first discovered this song from the band Junip. When I realized that it‚Äôs a cover of Bruce Springsteen, I found the original, and loved it, too.

This morning, it‚Äôs so cold outside, that neither my dog nor myself want to go outside any longer than is absolutely necessary. But, there are people out there, living in tents and sleeping bags.

I woke up to this song playing, I had left my phone on shuffle all night to help me sleep. I listened to it, looked at the weather, then became obsessed.

I‚Äôd never played this song before, but I learned it, then I recorded all the guitar and bass parts, and sang the vocal, and recorded it, and mixed it. Basically my whole Sunday went into this.

I plan to make a video for it, but I wanted to get this out, because I worked on it nonstop all day.

The Ghost of Tom Joad

Men walkin‚Äô ‚Äòlong the railroad tracks

Goin‚Äô someplace there‚Äôs no goin‚Äô back

Highway patrol choppers

Comin‚Äô up over the ridge

Hot soup on a campfire under the bridge

Shelter line stretchin‚Äô ‚Äôround the corner

Welcome to the new world order

Families sleepin‚Äô in their cars in the Southwest,

No home no job no peace no rest

The highway is alive tonight

But nobody‚Äôs kiddin‚Äô nobody

About where it goes

I‚Äôm sittin‚Äô down here in the campfire light Searchin‚Äô for the ghost of Tom Joad

He pulls a prayer book out of his sleeping bag Preacher lights up a butt and takes a drag

Waitin‚Äô for when the last shall be first, and

The first shall be last

In a cardboard box ‚Äòneath the underpass

Got a one¬≠way ticket to the promised land

You got a hole in your belly and gun in your hand Sleeping on a pillow of solid rock

Bathin‚Äô in the city aqueduct

The highway is alive tonight

Where it‚Äôs headed everybody knows

I‚Äôm sittin‚Äô down here in the campfire light

Waitin‚Äô on the ghost of Tom Joad

Now Tom said,

‚ÄúMom, wherever there‚Äôs a cop beatin‚Äô a guy

‚ÄúThe Ghost Of Tom Joad‚Äù lyrics

Wherever a hungry newborn baby cries

Where there‚Äôs a fight ‚Äògainst the blood and

Hatred in the air Look for me Mom I‚Äôll be there

‚ÄúWherever there‚Äôs somebody fightin‚Äô

For a place to stand

Or decent job or a helpin‚Äô hand

Wherever somebody‚Äôs strugglin‚Äô to be free

Look in their eyes Mom you‚Äôll see me.‚Äù

Well the highway is alive tonight

But nobody‚Äôs kiddin‚Äô nobody

About where it goes

I‚Äôm sittin‚Äô down here in the campfire light

With the ghost of old Tom Joad

Words and music by Bruce Springsteen

This was a refreshingly positive experience. With every post I make on Instagram, I get hit up multiple times for paid promotions. It‚Äôs always a sleazy approach like ‚ÄúI love your stuff! Let‚Äôs work together!‚Äù even though you know they sent that message so fast, they couldn‚Äôt possibly have listened to the song.

This guy Bobby asked me on TikTok if he could review me on his show tonight. I said yes, but I was thinking, ‚ÄúWait for it‚Ä¶ he‚Äôs going to hit me with a dollar amount, a pay-to-play thing.‚Äù I don‚Äôt do those. But he didn‚Äôt ask for anything. He‚Äôs got a pretty intelligent approach to it, he offers pay-to-play, but also gives free plays and reviews, no questions asked.

He played a few minutes of my song (the format is that each song gets roughly two minutes, so he can fit more into the show). He gave some kind feedback on it and all he asks is that viewers stay active in the chats, giving ratings for each song (he uses a 1-1,000 rating scale). Even though most of what got played was either hip hop or rap, he stayed open to other genres. My music is really different from everything else I heard tonight, but he gave it equal time and thoughtful consideration.

In the chats, it looks like people rated my tune anywhere from 600 to 1,000 with an average of maybe 800 or 900. One person said 2,000 but that‚Äôs not inside the range you‚Äôre supposed to use ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏èüôÉ

I was pleased, especially since most of the people there were making hip hop music. He asked everyone to add constructive criticism to any songs that they rated low, and said no hating on anyone. The overall thing was a nice surprise for sure.

You can catch his show and submit your music for consideration at: Bobby Everything

New Album on June 8th

This album has the song on it that was reviewed in the show. The song is called ‚ÄúWhite Elephant.‚Äù You can watch the full video here:

Support

Get exclusive bonus material at Patreon

‚ÄúAll Around‚Äù ‚Äì music by Trent Boswell

I can‚Äôt find it I don‚Äôt see it

Though I‚Äôve looked nowhere over

I was certain I‚Äôd have found it

By now

Thought I had it once

In my hand like a clover

But it flew away

Somehow

I‚Äôve rubbed out my eyes

Squinting through the dark

But my eyes are too full

Of dreams

Want nothing so much

Thoughts of self not a spark

And I still do not know

What it means

Collecting each one

Not mine in a moment

All tomorrow‚Äôs

Forgotten yesterday

Yourself saw you with them

You know of the torment

A sideways hello

Didn‚Äôt say

Slippery little thing

So many to climb

Fall so fast and without

A sound

Never had your gift

Of yours all this time

Wrapped tight and spilling

On the ground

All time gone by

Flirting with the dawn

Seeking for a higher

High score

Those things which remain

To this day are long gone

These things are all things

No more

Don‚Äôt know why I bother

I bother not to know

It‚Äôs never too much

Not to say

A slight tinge of joy

In each thing to show

Everything never came

This way

The secret only shared

Never told never kept

All the smiles that cannot

Be got

Always not moving

Ever happy it wept

In the open it hides

Where it‚Äôs not

Close the window my friend

Despite how it looks

It is going to be

A fine day

For it has the good sense

In verbose old books

All words refraining

To say

A slight tiny sting

Four missing leaves of clover

Ending all applause

Curtain bow

Can‚Äôt find it don‚Äôt see it

Having looked all over

Was certain I‚Äôd have lost it

By now

¬©2022 Kevin Trent Boswell

Lyrics available in print:

War on Venus ‚Äì Original music by Magus

I posted this song before, but I have entirely remixed it. The new mix sounds far superior to the original. I also shortened the title from ‚ÄúTales of War On Venus‚Äù to ‚ÄúWar on Venus.‚Äù

Lyrics:

We sit, swapping war stories

We‚Äôve barred all the windows and doors

Each of us covered in blood

Half of it mine, half of it yours

Two chairs, sitting face to face

The room is bare, otherwise

Suspiciously watching each other for

Sudden movements, any shift in the eyes

There‚Äôs a word for why we‚Äôre here

The trap, it fits us like a glove

Explains all the mess and the misery

And that four-letter word is love

Pause long enough to take a shot

From the big bottle of poison

We‚Äôre not much but we‚Äôre all that we‚Äôve got

We sweat bullets and swear ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre the one.

You‚Äôre the only one for me.‚Äù

Weapons at the ready, there in our laps

Fingers never far from the trigger

No one smiles, no one eats or sleeps

Shots of whiskey and resentment get bigger

It‚Äôs no mystery how or where

We both know who‚Äôs to blame, we insist

Each of us swearing that the other struck first

It was a case of love at first fist

There‚Äôs a word for why we‚Äôre here

This trap, it fits us like a glove

Explains all the mess and misery

And that four-letter word is love

¬©Ô∏è2022 Kevin Trent Boswell

Video clips by:

cottonbro

MART PRODUCTION

Eugene Vasilevich

and Alex Green, Timur Weber, Diva Plavalaguna, Gustavo Fring

This is a song that I wrote in my early twenties but until now, no proper recording of it existed.

In the past year, I‚Äôve learned several truckloads about ‚Äúdesktop music production‚Äù and how to get studio-quality recordings, using only my computer DAW (audio recording program) a basic, two input audio interface and a simple, Shure-58, dynamic microphone.

Also, I finally got a decent pair of studio monitors, so I can hear what is actually going on in the mix, without it being colored too much by the automatic tweaking of frequencies that is present in most speaker systems.

These factors combined, I‚Äôm now putting out recordings that are vastly superior to what I was producing last year. The latest material is sonically improved at least a couple hundred percent.

Lyrics

Sometimes I find out things about me

Just a little bit more than I‚Äôd ever want to know

Kind of put a damper on a real good mood

Just when I was sure I was on a roll

I was sure I was

In the face of greatness, we often feel small

Yeah, the Full Moon, she spits in my eye

And wouldn‚Äôt we all just love to know

Ooh, yeah‚Ä¶ exactly why

I know I would

I look for answers in the other dimensions

I listen for stories that cannot be told

I seek someone to take my confessions

And if there is no one, then I want control

God knows, I could use some control

Control

If you could only see what I saw

You‚Äôd surely say that I‚Äôd lost my mind

But I know it‚Äôs true that all are one and one is all

I‚Äôve seen it going on, all the time

Anyway you turn the question,

It cannot be answered

But anyway you turn the answer,

It cannot be questioned

I took a toothless profession in cancer

On a slighted word, best not to mention

No, no

And I look for answers in the other dimensions

I listen for stories that cannot be told

And I‚Äôll do anything for direction

Anything short of sell my soul

If I‚Äôve got one to bargain away

Away

Away

¬©2022 Kevin Trent Boswell

from the album Something in the Air, by Trent Boswell, 2022

This is ‚ÄúSomething Like A Rainbow‚Äù, my first Orchestral Pop song.

It‚Äôs only a string section, not an entire orchestra. But what sets this apart from anything that I‚Äôve ever done before is that, in addition to writing the chord progression, the guitar and bass parts and the lyrics, I also wrote the string part. That‚Äôs a new one for me.

And I didn‚Äôt just write something on guitar and then transpose it for strings. Instead, I wrote it the way a classical composer would.

To do this, I had to draw on the part writing rules that we learned in music theory class in college, something that I thought I‚Äôd never actually use. It was a long time ago, so I feel sure that I broke some of those rules in various places but remembering the basics (no parallel 4ths or 5ths, etc) got me through it.

Something Like A Rainbow

Lost and alone and wandering

Finding a true friend there, in the rain

Hold fast, together

Warmth in a lover‚Äôs arms

Loving each other heals the pain

A soft and gentle light, to lead the way

Something like a rainbow

So many things we were told we‚Äôd see

Most of them never came to be

But no one can explain the redeeming grace

That shines from the light in your face

A soft and gentle light, it leads the way

Something like a rainbow

And it shines into forever

Walk in its light, into forever

So many things we were told we‚Äôd see

Most of them never came to be

Still, no one can explain the redeeming grace

That shines when a smile is upon your face

A soft and gentle light, it leads the way

Something like a rainbow

Soft and gentle light, it leads the way

Something like a rainbow

And its light goes into forever

Ride the light into forever

All music and lyrics ¬©2022 Kevin Trent Boswell, from the album Something in the Air

Here is my cover of ‚ÄúHoochie Coochie Man‚Äù. This tune was written by the preeminent Godfather of the Blues, Muddy Waters.

The lyrics are heavily laced with references to the Hoodoo conjure tradition of the American South. One commonly misunderstood line is:

I got the John the Conqueror Root

I‚Äôm gonna mess with you

To mess with someone was to put roots on them, meaning to cast spells on that person.

The root known as John the Conqueror (Ipomoea jalapa) is widely regarded as one of the most powerful roots or Plant Spirits; if not the most powerful.

The root, all by itself, was potent and to possess it was to hold power to exert one‚Äôs will. However, to possess a mojo hand (aka, mojo bag), made and empowered by a knowledgeable rootworker, was an awe-inspiring thing.

It was not a simple matter to travel to Louisiana and get a mojo, especially for a Black person, who had less opportunities and greater obstacles. If you wanted the magick, the only way to get it was to find a skilled doctor.

This was a man or woman who knew how to coerce the Spirits to work on their behalf. First, you had to find a rootworker and then you had to convince them to make a hand for you and pay them whatever their fee was, no questions asked.

Any rituals they prescribed you or tasks assigned must be followed scrupulously. But once you had a mojo hand, especially one containing John the Conqueror, it meant that you were a force to be reckoned with.

I‚Äôm doing all the guitar, bass and vocal parts on this track. I added Slight Return to the title as a little tip of the hat to another major influence of mine, the immortal Jimi Hendrix. Hendrix was well aware of the lore mentioned here and his song ‚ÄúVoodoo Child (Slight Return)‚Äù references similar themes.

During the last verse, you‚Äôll see a quote, placed over a pic of Muddy Waters. It comes from the movie Crossroads, starring Ralph Machio; not to be confused with the movie Crossroads, starring Britney Spears.

It‚Äôs the story of a young, classical guitarist who dreams of nothing but playing the Mississippi Delta Blues. He‚Äôs a classical music major at The Juilliard School of Music but is mostly obsessed with Robert Johnson, arguably the greatest blues man ever.

Support the creation of more

music, poetry and madness

The images in this video are

1) historic pictures of famous, Hoodoo rootworkers and practitioners of Voodoo (or Voudon, Voodou, etc) and a few that just look the part.

2) pictures of myself playing guitar

3) personal photos and video of workings I‚Äôve done

4) random, ‚Äúbluesy‚Äù stuff that gives the appropriate, Mississippi Blues vibe or the Hoodoo/Voodoo, sorcery vibe

5) images from The Key of Solomon, a European magickal grimoire (which became highly important in Hoodoo.

6) stock footage, provided by:

This is the video for Unchanged. The .mp3 song download is available for patrons, over at Patreon.

It‚Äôs an original, definitely in the vein of my signature brand, a type of madness so strange that I had to give it a new name. I call it Purple Mind Licorice Music¬ÆÔ∏è.

It combines alternative rock, funk, jazz, folk, blues, heavy metal and psychedelia. It‚Äôs a long name but Parliament already has Funkadelic and well, let‚Äôs face it, Alterna-Funk-N-Roll isn‚Äôt nearly as sexy as Purple Mind Licorice Music. Why yes, I do tend to talk about my music like James Brown talked about his. Thank you for noticing.

Side note, if you haven‚Äôt seen the film , it‚Äôs surprisingly good. I‚Äôm a big fan of The Godfather of Soul, The Minister Of New New Super Heavy Funk (even if he was a total wacko, in real life). But for whatever reason, I didn‚Äôt think the movie would be all that great. I was delightfully wrong.

Besides, alternative is a lousy category. Any genre that contains Nirvana, REM, Alice In Chains, Weezer, Coldplay and Bush isn‚Äôt particularly helpful in guiding listeners‚Äô decisions. They seriously need to scrap that garbage and revisit the drawing board.Back to the business at hand. I‚Äôve played this song live in my band but we just never managed to get a decent recording of it.

I‚Äôm doing the vocal and all the bass and guitar parts. Here, I abandoned my memories of how we played it in the band and just started from scratch, all by myself, just me and my computer drummer, Stinky the Robot.

Fake It ‚ÄòTil You Break It

I‚Äôve got a habit of improvising my lead guitar parts, as opposed to writing out a solo in advance. There are songs that I write solos for but those are special cases. Usually, I just improvise and keep the bits that I like.

If anyone takes issue with that, many years ago I read an interview with David Gilmour (Pink Floyd) in a guitar magazine. He said that‚Äôs the same process he uses in the studio.

He would take several, improv passes at a song, then cut and paste the bits he liked. Later, he‚Äôd go back and learn those parts for the live shows.

Comfortably Numb was done that way and I think that song did alright. It sold like over a thousand copies or something. Trust me‚Ä¶ in my head, that joke was hysterical.

Of course, I also have a habit of keeping what I regard as being some of ‚Äúthe more charming mistakes‚Äú, for better or for worse. There‚Äôs one or two of those in the jam section at the end of this tune. I was tempted to re-record those bits but if they make me giggle, then they stay. Giggles are a precious commodity, not to be wasted.

Unchanged

These wounds, open and tender

Reveal your face to me

Into the chalice of my arms

The blood of your suffering flows free

It‚Äôs a mild mannered possession,

This waiting for the rain

Encumbered by the spell and

Groggy in the slumbering delay

A scrap of ribbon, fallen

From a lover‚Äôs hair

Found by the boots of boredom

Lament for things not yet dead

A piece of my soul floats there

Down in the puddle below

Somewhere in a watch pocket

An insane notion explodes

All words and music

¬© 2021 Kevin Trent Boswell

This is my cover of the song ‚ÄúThe Weight‚Äù by that excellent group known simply as The Band.

‚ÄúIt consisted of four Canadians and one American: Rick Danko (bass guitar, vocals, fiddle), Garth Hudson (keyboards, accordion, saxophone), Richard Manuel (keyboards, drums, vocals), Robbie Robertson (guitar, vocals), and Levon Helm (drums, vocals, mandolin, guitar).‚Äù

Source: https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Band

I‚Äôve had a deep love of this song for as long as I can remember. It‚Äôs got a fun, upbeat vibe to the music but the lyrics (as the title suggests) are very heavy.

It‚Äôs a song about loneliness, disappointment and suffering. It‚Äôs about asking where you turn when all your best laid plans have fallen apart.

When I do a cover song, I usually try to reinvent it to some degree. I try to put something of my own mark on it. In this case, it didn‚Äôt feel right to completely reshape the song. There are really only two ways that I‚Äôve wandered away from the original.

One is that I had to somehow fill up the empty space left by Garth‚Äôs piano playing. I chose to do that with harmony guitar parts, because guitar is my instrument and I gave them a simple and slightly somber quality, to accent the lyrics.

The other is that I shortened the chorus and used heavy effects on the vocal harmonies. I‚Äôm doing all the vocal, guitar and bass parts on this. The drums are by Stinky the Robot, my computer-based drummer, who is even more difficult to work with than a real drummer, if that‚Äôs even possible.

Gratitude

Special thanks to the following people for providing the evocative video footage that helps bring to light our social problem of the lost and disenfranchised. Homelessness and mental illness are entirely too prevalent and much more needs to be done.

We can‚Äôt be a healthy society unless we take care of our own and that means everyone, however unpleasant it might be to look into that chasm and think ‚ÄúThere, but for the grace of God, go I.‚Äù We must do more‚Ä¶ much more.

If you have the means to do so, please donate your money and your volunteer time to one or more of the many quality organizations that offer help to the homeless, the mentally challenged and to stray animals. Most of the people and animals on the street got there by bad luck and they deserve a second chance.

MART PRODUCTION

RODNAE Productions

Music video for ‚ÄúInto the Fold‚Äù. Song was recorded live by Magus & The Plastic Infinity, at a club in Wilmington, NC.

Guitar and vocals by Trent Boswell. All music and lyrics written by Trent Boswell.

Lyrics:

Into the Fold

Please bring me into the fold

I long for warmth from cold

I can‚Äôt seem to bear the load

And my anger like a stone

I‚Äôve been let down again

They slip right in and call me friend

Lunged at again

I‚Äôd prefer another end

Before they leave, you know they lie

Infiltrate and try

To burn my hopes alive;

Cast my dreams aside

I need myself a family

That can protect; I cannot feed

The one I have is so in need

You see the way the story goes

The king is allergic to his clothes

The tragedy is known; it shows

I‚Äôve no idea to ride

The coattails of another‚Äôs pride

But if it were to mean my hide

Suppose I‚Äôd give it half a try

It has come to seem to me

That the mafioso creed

Is a safe bet when in need

Of a haven in which to bleed

She will kiss and he will crunch

Her kiss hurts more, packs more punch

Unfortunately, not a hunch;

It‚Äôs all out to lunch

I need myself a family

That can protect; I cannot feed

The one I have is so in need

¬© 2021 Kevin Trent Boswell

Music video for ‚ÄúFear & Lies‚Äù, a song from the album Flagship by Trent Boswell.

Lyrics:

Fear & Lies

Many are they

Who have whispered lies

Many are they

Who have made me despise

Many are the lies

And many who have heard

She knows that I could love her

If not for fear of that word

You know that I‚Äôll try

Put a little sunlight in your eye

You know that I‚Äôll try

Put a little shine in your smile

And you know that

You can come with me, anytime

But you know that I have fear

Of the fear and the lies

¬© 2021 Kevin Trent Boswell

Music video for ‚ÄúLooking For A Way‚Äù, a song from the album Flagship by Trent Boswell.

Lyrics:

Looking For A Way

I climbed like a monkey, up in a tree

Trying to find a piece of me

Way up in the branches so high

I found that I cannot fly‚Ä¶ as of yet

But I‚Äôm looking for a way

I‚Äôm at fault for inciting the madness

And sometimes I can‚Äôt stop the sadness

But I‚Äôm learning to ride waves of joy

Toward manhood moves a boy

Looking for a way

I got dizzy and fell like a lion

Into the dust of Orion

Those stars; the ones up in the sky;

The one he made up in his mind,

The one that‚Äôs still looking

Looking for a way

And I haven‚Äôt quit yet

¬© 2021 Kevin Trent Boswell

You may think you‚Äôve seen this one but you ain‚Äôt. The new, improved and at least 333% stranger version of ‚ÄúPerception‚Äù from the album Flagship by Trent Boswell.

Lyrics:

Perception

What‚Äôs a man supposed to do?

It‚Äôs hard today just not to lose

So, when I‚Äôm down and beaten blue

I look around and think of you

Sink into my contemplation

Answers come with concentration

And strong opinions, well I have mine

And you may find me blind

But I don‚Äôt mind because it‚Äôs true;

I‚Äôve never needed to see you

Walking ‚Äòcross the field,

I realize that nothing‚Äôs real

No pain or joy

Out on the lawn the past is gone

I simply can‚Äôt be wrong anymore

Was paid a visit, a strange man

He said that Jesus could lend a hand

Now many a man can‚Äôt see the road

Or make a stand on his own

If God is Love, then Love is God

And you agree without a nod

If you like bands like Queens of the Stone Age, Jane‚Äôs Addiction, Jimi Hendrix or The Mars Volta, then you‚Äôll probably dig this.

This is a brand new recording of the song that I wrote many years ago but never had a chance to record it until now. I‚Äôve played it live with my band quite a few times but unfortunately, we never caught it on tape.

I‚Äôm playing the bass and guitar parts and singing. Everything that you hear on this track is me, except for the drums. That‚Äôs because I don‚Äôt have access to a live drummer right now. Besides, feeding and caring for a wild animal like that is expensive.

Here‚Äôs the full video on YouTube. Don‚Äôt forget to hit the thumbs up üëç subscribe ‚úÖ and the notifications bell üîî

The song is called blind in the sun and the lyrics are below. Originally, it was a poem and I set it to music (hence the Roman numerals in the lyrics).

The .mp3 file is attached to my Patreon page, so you can go there, download it (for free) and play it whenever you want.

I forget sometimes that people don‚Äôt always follow my rather eccentric, artistic choices, so I will explain something about this track. I purposefully chose not to clean up the sloppier guitar licks on this track, because it‚Äôs the feel that I was going for‚Ä¶ teetering on the edge of the abyss.

Going back and punching in smoother, cleaner guitar parts is easy enough. I just didn‚Äôt want ‚Äôem, not for this. I‚Äôll mention two songs that inspired my playing on this. One is ‚ÄúGod‚Äù, by Tori Amos. Her guitar player is way better than he sounds on that track. It‚Äôs dirty, gritty and foul, for a reason. The song is about existential angst and the loss of faith, so it‚Äôs gotta be grimy.

The other is ‚ÄúCome On (Let The Good Times Roll)‚Äù by The Jimi Hendrix Experience. On that song, he does what jazz musicians refer to as ‚Äúgoing outside‚Äù, meaning that he lets his solos wander just a little bit out of time and out of key, on purpose. Of course, he brings it back in or it wouldn‚Äôt be interesting. I chose to step outside on this track but hopefully not too much.

Feel free to share the link to this page or the Patreon page, or the YouTube link on your social media, that‚Äôs the best form of advertising there is for underground artists. I thank you in advance. Enjoy!

Just click that big, unwieldy link, below, to listen to the track. Or go to the Patreon page. You can download the song from the Patreon page and have it for your very own. Just don‚Äôt forget to water it every few days and never feed it after midnight.

Blind In The Sun

https://c10.patreonusercontent.com/3/eyJhIjoxLCJwIjoxfQ%3D%3D/patreon-media/p/post/45543356/0114204adf4a4bb2b4c492b3e1d80cbd/1.mp3?token-time=1609345733&token-hash=2ZL8WItz55_ogZDHvUN7Am6ticXKPOwsOUgMUTJy7_k%3D

I.

Blind in the Sun‚†Ä

Can you cringe beneath

The shadow of a fly?

You‚Äôd better try

Running ‚Äòcross the sand

Fire in the hearts of your band

In the joy of being alive

Stripped of delusion

And so forwardly stride

Lost in the garden

with canonized illusions

There are the keepers

Of the tower

But I am not a member

Of the dark December

The light of the sun refracts

In my eye

II.

Everything is water

Electric fluid matter

In a paper cup

Called Time

III.

Somewhere in the North

There are real vampires

I know you go to visit

From time to time

To roll in the stench

The decadence of

Thirst for blood

To dine with a pack

Of wild gods

I have no intent

Of adopting your bent;

Partying down with the devil

On your shoulder

I have no intent

Of going where you went

Beating on a skull

In a hellish midnight circle

But who am I to say?

That you are not ok?

I will simply stay

Behind
